block.p: Around Town
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURaL HISTORY Central Park West and 79th Street. In the recently opened Anne and Bernard Spitzer Hall of Human Origins, there are more than 200 casts of prehuman and human fossils and artifacts that illustrate stages in physical and behavioral evolution. Through Aug. 19, ''Gold,'' with coins, jewelry and other artifacts. Through May 28, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' a display with hundreds of butterflies in a re-creation of their natural habitat. In the Imax theater, ''Roving Mars,'' a film about NASA's Mars Rover. Timed tickets to ''Gold'' and ''The Butterfly Conservatory,'' which include museum admission, are $21; $16 for students and 60+; $12 for 12 and younger. Imax tickets, which include museum admission, are $21; $16 for students and 60+; $12 for children 12 and under. Suggested museum admission: $14; $10.50 for students and 60+; children, $8. Combination tickets, including museum and Rose Center admission and the Hayden Planetarium space show (''Cosmic Collisions''): $22; $16.50 for students and 60+; $13 for 12 and younger; under 2, free. Admission that includes all activities: $30; $23 for students and 60+; $19 for 12 and younger. The Rose Center is open until 8:45 p.m. for ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' with jazz, a cash bar and tapas, on the first Friday of every month; tonight at 6 and 7:30, Eric Lewis. Museum hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. (to 8:45 p.m. on Fridays). (212) 769-5100 or (212) 769-5200; amnh.org.

HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmond Town. Tavern Concert Series: tomorrow at 7:30 and 9 p.m., the North River Band; $12. Through April 1, ''Out of Fire and Valor: Staten Island War Memorials,'' photographs by Cal Snyder, a Marine Corps veteran. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. $5; $4 for 62+; $3.50 for students and 5 to 17; free for children under 5 and members; (718) 351-1611.

MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, East Village. Thursday at 6:30 p.m., ''A Tale of Two Chandeliers,'' a historical look at the lighting of the museum, including a discussion about the restoration and updating of its lighting system. $10; free for members. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 5 p.m. $8; $5 for students and 65+; free for members and under 12. (212) 777-1089.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. Tonight at 7, ''Winterkill,'' a one-woman show in celebration of Women's History Month, featuring Denise B. Flemming. Through May 28, ''Robert Moses and the Modern City: Remaking the Metropolis,'' one of three exhibitions dedicated to Moses at cultural institutions in the city; the others are at the Queens Museum of Art and the Wallach Art Gallery at Columbia University. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $9; $5 for students and 62+; free for children under 12; $20 for families; free on Sundays, 10 a.m. to noon. (212) 534-1672, mcny.org.

NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN, United States Custom House, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan. Opening tomorrow, ''Off the Map: Landscape in the Native Imagination,'' an exhibition of paintings, drawings, sculpture and installations devoted to the representation of landscape. Through May, ''Born of Clay: Ceramics From the National Museum of the American Indian.'' Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m.; free; (212) 514-3700, www.nmai.si.edu.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 2 West 77th Street, Manhattan. Monday at 7:30 p.m., ''George Gershwin Songbook,'' a gala presented by the American Musicals Project featuring arrangements of 18 of Gershwin's songs, performed by Victoria Clark, with piano accompaniment by Linda Hall; $75 to $500; (212) 873-3400, Ext. 305. Through May 20, ''Carry Me Home: Dispatches From the Civil War,'' an exhibition of letters, photographs and other documents that illustrate firsthand accounts of the war from the front lines. Through Sept. 3, ''New York Divided: Slavery and the Civil War,'' a display of historical documents, photographs, political cartoons and other items. Through July 1, ''Elegy in the Dust: Sept. 11 and the Chelsea Jeans Memorial,'' a glass-encased time capsule of items from that retail store at the time of the 9/11 attack, along with photographs from the society's collection that document events that day. Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; to 8 p.m. on Fridays. $10; $7 for educators and 65+; $6 for students; free from 6 to 8 p.m. on Fridays, free at all times for children under 12. (212) 873-3400; nyhistory.org.
Events

ART EXPO NEW YORK, Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, 655 West 34th Street, Manhattan. Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., and Monday, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., with more than 600 exhibitors of fine and popular art. $12; $5 for students; free for those under 12. artexpos.com.

92ND STREET Y 1395 Lexington Avenue. Sunday at 6:30 p.m., a screening of ''Loose Change,'' a documentary about the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, followed by a discussion with its filmmakers, Dylan Avery, Jason Bermas and Korey Rowe: $25. Monday at 7:30 p.m., ''Why Hannah Arendt Matters,'' a discussion with Elisabeth Young-Bruehl, an author and psychoanalyst who studied under Ms. Arendt; $25. Also Monday at 8 p.m., a poetry reading in celebration of the centennial of the birth of the poet W. H. Auden, featuring Shirley Hazzard, the author; Ned Rorem, the composer; Charles Rosen, the pianist; and Oliver Sacks, the author and neurologist; $18. (212) 415-5500.

'CLASH OF THE ARTISTS,' 15 West 28th Street, 10th floor, Chelsea. Tomorrow, 7 p.m. to 1 a.m., a party and competition that features visual artists, musicians, filmmakers, D.J.s and others; $25 in advance, $30 at the door. Sponsored by Art for Progress. artforprogress.org.

BROOKLYN PUBLIC LIBRARY, Grand Army Plaza, at Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway. Women's History Month Events. Tomorrow at 4 p.m., a screening of ''In the Shadow of Little Rock,'' a work in progress by Sharon LaCruise about the civil rights leader Daisy Bates. Sunday at 2 p.m., a discussion with Vivian Gornick, author of ''The Solitude of Self: Thinking About Elizabeth Cady Stanton.'' Both events are free. (718) 230-2100.

'STRANGE DAYS ON PLANET EARTH: THE ONE DEGREE FACTOR,' New York Aquarium, Surf Avenue and West Eighth Street, Coney Island, Brooklyn, (718) 265-3474. Tomorrow at 10 and 11:50 a.m. and 12:55, 2:45 and 4:35 p.m., sessions on global warming that include screenings of a short film. Sponsored by the Aquarium, Yale University and the Sea Studio Foundation. Free.

'HOUSE OF RAIN,' Explorers Club, 46 East 70th Street, Manhattan. Monday at 7 p.m., a lecture about the Anasazi peoples of the American Southwest, by Craig Childs, an author and naturalist. $20; $5 for students. explorers.org.

OPEN STUDIOS; 'NEW ART NEW YORK,' New York University, Steinhardt School of Culture, Education and Human Development, Department of Art and Art Professions, 34 Stuyvesant Street, Lower Manhattan. Today, 6 to 9 p.m. and tomorrow, noon to 6 p.m., artwork by undergraduate and graduate art students will be on view. Free. (212) 998-5799.
Spoken Word

CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK GRADUATE CENTER, 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street. Monday at 6 p.m., ''Is There a New European Anti-Semitism?,'' a lecture by Pierre Birnbaum, a French political sociologist and history professor. Monday at 6:30 p.m., ''After '68: French Film, History and Politics in the 1970's,'' a discussion with Jean-Michel Frodon, a French professor, and others. Both are free. (212) 817-8215.

SOUTH STREET SEAPORT MUSEUM, 12 Fulton Street, Lower Manhattan. Thursday at 6 p.m., a book talk about ''She Captains: Heroines and Hellions of the Sea,'' by Joan Druett. Free, but reservations required: (212) 748-8568.

'STATIC: GOVERNMENT LIARS, MEDIA CHEERLEADERS AND THE PEOPLE WHO FIGHT BACK,' Council Senior Center, 241 West 72nd Street, Manhattan. Sunday at 1 p.m., a lecture by Amy Goodman, the executive producer of ''Democracy Now!,'' a daily radio and television news program. Sponsored by the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged. Free. Registration: (212) 273-5304.
POETRY READING TO CELEBRATE THE PUSHCART PRIZE, Baruch Performing Arts Center, 55 Lexington Avenue, at 25th Street, Manhattan. Thursday at 7 p.m., featuring six American poets. Free. (646) 312-4085.

GENERAL SOCIETY OF MECHANICS AND TRADESMEN, 20 West 44th Street, Manhattan. Monday at 7 p.m., a lecture on the evolution of classicism in European and American studios after 1850, by Peter Trippi, editor of Fine Art Connoisseur and former director of the Dahesh Museum of Art; a reception is planned at 6:30 p.m. Also sponsored by the Grand Central Academy of the Institute of Classical Architecture and Classical America. $10; free for members. Reservations: (212) 730-9646, Ext. 109.

NEW SCHOOL, 66 West 12th Street, Greenwich Village. Monday at 6:30 p.m., a reading by Lynne Tillman from her book ''American Genius: A Comedy''; $5. Wednesday at 6:30 p.m., ''Women Writers of the Diaspora,'' a series of readings and discussions; free. newschool.edu.
Walking Tours

BIG ONION WALKING TOURS Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Historic Harlem,'' meeting at the Schomburg Center, on the northwest corner of 135th Street and Lenox Avenue. Sunday at 1 p.m., the ''Jewish Lower East Side,'' meeting on the southeast corner of Essex and Delancey Streets. $15 each; $12 for 63+; $10 for students and New-York Historical Society members. (212) 439-1090; bigonion.com.

ELLIS ISLAND TOUR, meeting tomorrow at 9 a.m. at the PATH train canopy at Church and Vesey Streets, Lower Manhattan. Includes sites in Lower Manhattan and Liberty State Park. Led by Tom Bernardin. $25, not including water taxi and ferry fares. (212) 209-3370.

'GRAND CENTRAL TERMINAL: CROSSROADS OF A MILLION PRIVATE LIVES,' Sunday at 1 p.m., meeting at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Altria, 42nd Street and Park Avenue. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. $15; 65+, $12; (212) 242-5762.

NYC DISCOVERY TOURS Tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m., ''NoHo and the East Village,'' a look at neighborhoods that drew the struggling and well-heeled in the 1800s. Tomorrow at 5 p.m., ''Union Square Historic Tavern Tour.'' Fee for each: $14, with drinks additional for the tavern tour. Reservations and meeting places: (212) 465-3331.

EAST VILLAGE WALKING TOUR, tomorrow at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m., meeting at the cube in Astor Place, East Village. Sponsored by East-village.com. $12; $8 for Lower East Side residents; $5 for 65+ and students. (646) 810-2576.

STREET SMARTS N.Y. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''From Union Square to Madison Square: In Teddy's Footsteps'' focuses on the life of Theodore Roosevelt, meeting in front of the Barnes & Noble at 33 East 17th Street, Flatiron district. $10. (212) 969-8262.

BROOKLYN CENTER FOR THE URBAN ENVIRONMENt Tomorrow at 11 a.m., ''Old Theaters of the East Village,'' meeting on the corner of East Eighth Street and Third Avenue. $13; members, $10; students and 63+, $8. (718) 788-8500, Ext. 208.

'CHELSEA YESTERDAY AND TODAY,' with stops in the meatpacking district and at Chelsea Market and Chelsea Piers, meeting tomorrow at 1 p.m. on the northwest corner of 15th Street and Ninth Avenue. Sponsored by I'll Take Manhattan Tours. $15. (732) 270-5559.

'HELL'S KITCHEN-A-POPPIN; THEN AND NOW' Sunday at 11 a.m., the residential, business and theatrical histories of the area, meeting on the northwest corner of Ninth Avenue and 59th Street. Sponsored by Bonnie's Lost New York Walks and Talks. $15. (212) 594-8039.

MUNICIPAL ART SOCIETY Tomorrow at 11 a.m., ''Times Square Theaters: A New Century, a New Style,'' architectural trends of the theater district through the 20th century, meeting on the steps of the New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street. $15; $12 for members. (212) 439-1049.

METRO TOUR SERVICE Mondays at 2 p.m. through March, a tour focusing on the African-American cultural presence in the Brooklyn neighborhoods Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant, meeting on the corner of Lafayette Avenue and Hanson Place in Fort Greene. Today and tomorrow at 2 p.m., Brooklyn Heights, Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. Sunday at 3 p.m., a gospel tour. These tours all meet in front of the Marriott Hotel, Adams and Tillary Streets, downtown Brooklyn. Each, $25. (718) 789-0430.
Recreation

COOGAN'S SALSA BLUES AND SHAMROCKS 5K RUN, Washington Heights. Sunday at 9 a.m., beginning at Fort Washington Avenue and 168th Street. Children's race follows at 10 a.m. Sponsored by New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration: $25; $17 for members; $13 for 18 and younger and 62+. Race-day registration: $35; $25 for members; $15 for 18 and younger and 62+. Children's race: $5. (212) 860-4455; nyrrc.org.
